questions.question: What are the two types of processes defined in the First Law of Thermodynamics?
Which statement best describes an isochoric process in thermodynamics?
options: It involves no exchange of heat

questions.question: Which principle is used to derive the Carnot efficiency?
What does the concept of entropy represent in the Second Law of Thermodynamics?
options: The total amount of energy in a system
The degree of randomness or disorder in a system
The pressure-volume product of a system
The measure of heat transferred per unit of time
questions.correct_answer: The degree of randomness or disorder in a system

questions.question: In a thermodynamic process, what does the area under the curve of a PV diagram (Pressure-Volume diagram) typically represent?
options: Work done by or on the system
questions.correct_answer: Work done by or on the system

questions.question: Which thermodynamic cycle is typically associated with refrigeration systems?
What is the change in internal energy of a system for a cyclic process?
What does the Joule-Thomson effect describe?
options: The change in temperature of a gas when it expands or compresses at constant enthalpy
The change in volume of a gas when it is heated or cooled at constant pressure
The change in pressure of a gas when it is heated or cooled at constant volume
The change in entropy of a gas when it expands or compresses at constant temperature
questions.correct_answer: The change in temperature of a gas when it expands or compresses at constant enthalpy

questions.question: Which thermodynamic quantity remains constant during an adiabatic process?
In the context of thermodynamics, what is 'hysteresis'?
options: The inability of a system to return to its original state after a change in temperature
The inability of a system to return to its original state after a change in pressure
The difference between the amount of heat added to a system and the amount of work done by the system
The difference between the path taken by a system to reach a certain state and the path taken to return to the original state
questions.correct_answer: The difference between the path taken by a system to reach a certain state and the path taken to return to the original state
